[[File:København 4xMC.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Law enforcement in Denmark|Danish Police]] in [[Copenhagen]]]] '''Crime in Denmark''' is combated by the [[Law enforcement in Denmark|Danish Police]] and other agencies.
== By type == === Murder === {{Further|List of countries by intentional homicide rate}}
In 2012, Denmark had a murder rate of 0.8 per 100,000 population.<ref name=UNODC/> There were a total of 54 murders in Denmark in 2017.<ref name=UNODC>{{cite web|url=https://www.unodc.org/gsh/en/index.html|title=UNODC: Global Study on Homicide|first=|last=agt|website=Unodc.org|accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
=== Corruption === {{Main|Corruption in Denmark}} According to the [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] 2012 from [[Transparency International]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Corruption Perception Index 2012|url=http://cpi.transparency.org/cpi2012/results/|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref> Denmark together with Finland and New Zealand, are the World's most transparent countries. Transparency International's Global Corruption Barometer 2013 shows that the public does not consider corruption a major problem in [[Danish society]], and bribes paid to access public benefits and services are virtually non-existent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Corruption Barometer 2013|url=http://www.transparency.org/gcb2013|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref>
=== Organised crime === The criminal [[biker gang]]s [[Bandidos Motorcycle Club|Bandidos]], [[Satudarah]] MC, [[Gremium]] MC, Loyal To Familia, Black Army and [[Hells Angels]] are present in Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGtwGQcF11o|title=YouTube|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, a gang war in [[Nørrebro]] culminated in multiple shooting incidents, which resulted in three deaths.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/tag/main/Bandekrig_i_Danmark|title=Bandekrig i Danmark|website=Politiken.dk|accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
== By location ==
[[Glostrup]], a blue-collar suburb in [[Copenhagen]] ranked as the most violent place in Denmark in 2009.<ref name="cphpost2">[http://www.cphpost.dk/news/crime/46814-copenhagen-suburb-tops-crime-stats.html Copenhagen suburb tops crime stats] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909043002/http://www.cphpost.dk/news/crime/46814-copenhagen-suburb-tops-crime-stats.html |date=2009-09-09 }}. Cphpost.dk (2009-09-04). Retrieved on 2011-06-12.</ref> The place with the fewest instances of reported violence was [[Christiansø]], a tiny island north east of [[Bornholm]].<ref name="cphpost2"/>
=== Copenhagen === Crime statistics for [[Copenhagen]] in 2011 revealed a 26 percent drop in arrests for violent threats and attacks and a 22 percent drop in drug-related arrests since 2009.<ref name="cphpost1">[http://www.cphpost.dk/news/crime/155-crime/51716-good-news-bad-news-in-crime-statistics.html Good news, bad news in crime statistics]. Cphpost.dk (2011-05-27). Retrieved on 2011-06-12.</ref> Crime statistics revealed a 24 percent rise in reported break-ins and home robberies in the city since 2009.<ref name="cphpost1"/>
== By ethnicity == {{See also|Immigration and crime in Denmark}} At 4%, male migrants aged 15-64 with non-Western backgrounds had twice the conviction rate against the [[Danish Penal Code]] in 2018, compared to 2% for Danish men. In a given year, about 13% of all male descendants of non-Western migrants aged 17-24 are convicted against the penal code.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dr.dk/ligetil/grafik-indvandrede-og-efterkommere-halter-efter-etniske-danskere|title=GRAFIK Indvandrede og efterkommere halter efter etniske danskere|work=DR|access-date=2018-07-14|language=da}}</ref>
==Resumption of border checks== On 4 January 2016, Denmark temporarily resumed checks along its borders with Germany and Sweden, previously open under the [[European Union|EU]]'s [[Schengen zone]] agreement.<ref name="telegraph1">Alexander, Harriet. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{See also|World population}} '''[[Demographics]] of the [[world]]''' include [[population density]], [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]], education level, health measures, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the human population of the planet [[Earth]]. The overall total population of the world is approximately 7.5 billion, as of March 2018. Its overall population density is 50 people per km² (129.28 per sq. mile), excluding Antarctica. Nearly two-thirds of the population lives in [[Asia]] and is predominantly urban and suburban, with more than 2.5 billion in the countries of [[China]] and [[India]] combined. The world's fairly low [[literacy]] rate (83.7%) is attributable to [[poverty]]. Lower literacy rates are common in [[South Asia]], [[West Asia]], and [[Sub-Saharan Africa]]. The world's largest ethnic group is [[Han Chinese]] with [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] being the world's most spoken language in terms of native speakers. Human migration has been shifting toward cities and urban centers, with the urban population jumping from 29% in 1950, to 50.5% in 2005.[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html CIA.gov World Factbook - World Statistics] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5nDzbMmsd?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |date=1 February 2010 }} Working backwards from the United Nations prediction that the world will be 51.3 percent urban by 2010, Dr. Ron Wimberley, Dr. Libby Morris and Dr. Gregory Fulkerson estimated 23 May 2007 to be the first time the urban population outnumbered the rural population in history.[http://www.gizmag.com/go/7334/ World Population Becomes More Urban That Rural] [[China]] and [[India]] are the most populous countries,{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2119rank.html |title=Country Comparison :: Population |accessdate=28 September 2011 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |year=2008 }} as the [[birth rate]] has consistently dropped in developed countries and until recently remained high in developing countries. [[Tokyo]] is the [[List of metropolitan areas by population|largest urban conglomeration]] in the world.{{cite web | url=http://www.geohive.com/earth/cy_notagg.aspx | title=Cities: largest (without surrounding suburban areas) | publisher=Geohive | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161205222859/http://www.geohive.com/earth/cy_notagg.aspx | archivedate=5 December 2016 | df= }} The [[total fertility rate]] of the World is estimated as 2.52 children per woman, which is above the global average for the [[replacement fertility rate]] of approximately 2.33 (as of 2003).{{cite journal|title=The surprising global variation in replacement fertility|vauthors=Espenshade TJ, Guzman JC, Westoff CF |year=2003|journal=Population Research and Policy Review | volume=22 |page=575 |doi=10.1023/B:POPU.0000020882.29684.8e |issue=5/6}}, Introduction and Table 1, p. 580 However, world [[population growth]] is unevenly distributed, with the total fertility rate going from .91 in [[Macau]], to 7.68 in [[Niger]]. The [[United Nations]] estimated an annual population increase of 1.14% for the year of 2000.{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/worldpop.html |title=Census.gov |publisher=Census.gov |date=7 January 2009 |accessdate=1 August 2010}} The current world population growth is approximately 1.09% People under 18 years of age made up over a quarter of the world population (29.3%), and people age 65 and over made up less than one-tenth (7.9%) in 2011. The world population more than tripled during the 20th century from about 1.65 billion in 1900 to 5.97 billion in 1999.[http://esa.un.org/unpp World Population Prospects]: The 2008 Revision Population Database {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5EykhvsD5?url=http://esa.un.org/unpp |date=7 April 2006 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/sixbillion/sixbillion.htm |title=The World at |publisher=Un.org |date=12 October 1999 |accessdate=1 August 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.globalchange.umich.edu/globalchange2/current/lectures/human_pop/human_pop.html |title=Population Growth over Human History |publisher=Globalchange.umich.edu |accessdate=1 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724101452/http://www.globalchange.umich.edu/globalchange2/current/lectures/human_pop/human_pop.html |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }} It reached the 2 billion mark in 1927, the 3 billion mark in 1960, 4 billion in 1974, and 5 billion in 1987.[http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0883352.html World Population Milestones] Currently, population growth is fastest among low wealth, [[Least Developed Countries]] countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/public/home/factsheets/pid/3856 |title=United Nations Population Fund |publisher=UNFPA |date=13 May 1968 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} The UN projects a world population of 9.15 billion in 2050, which is a 32.69% increase from 2010 (6.89 billion). {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px" ! ''[[Human|Homo sapiens]]'' appear to have occupied all of Africa about 150,000 years ago, moved out of Africa 50,000 - 60,000 years ago, and had spread across [[Prehistory of Australia|Australia]], [[History of Asia|Asia]] and [[Paleolithic Europe|Europe]] by 30,000 years BC. [[Models of migration to the New World|Migration to the Americas]] took place 20,000 to 15,000 years ago, and by 2,000 years ago, most of the [[Pacific Islands]] were colonized. Until c. 10,000 years ago, humans lived as [[hunter-gatherer]]s. They generally lived in small nomadic groups known as [[band societies]]. The advent of agriculture prompted the [[Neolithic Revolution]], when access to food surplus led to the formation of permanent [[human settlement]]s. About 6,000 years ago, the first proto-states developed in [[Mesopotamia]], [[Egypt]]'s [[Nile Valley]] and the [[Indus Valley Civilization|Indus Valley]]. Early human settlements were dependent on proximity to [[water resources|water]] and, depending on the [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]], other [[natural resources]] used for [[subsistence]]. But humans have a great capacity for altering their [[habitat (ecology)|habitats]] by means of technology. Since 1800, the [[human population]] has increased from one billion{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/411162.stm | accessdate = 5 February 2008 | work=BBC News | title=World's population reaches six billion | date=5 August 1999}} to over seven billion,{{cite web|title=UN population estimates.|url=http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/unpp/p2k0data.asp|work=Population Division, United Nations|accessdate=4 July 2013}} In 2004, some 2.5 billion out of 6.3 billion people (39.7%) lived in [[urban area]]s. In February 2008, the U.N. estimated that half the world's population would live in [[urban area]]s by the end of the year.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4561183.stm | work=BBC News | first=David | last=Whitehouse | title=Half of humanity set to go urban | date=19 May 2005}} Problems for humans living in [[city|cities]] include various forms of pollution and [[crime]],[http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/usrv98.pdf Urban, Suburban, and Rural Victimization, 1993–98] U.S. Department of Justice, Bureau of Justice Statistics,. Accessed 29 October 2006 especially in inner city and suburban [[slum]]s. Both overall population numbers and the proportion residing in cities are expected to increase significantly in the coming decades.{{cite web|title=World Urbanization Prospects, the 2011 Revision|url=http://esa.un.org/unup/CD-ROM/Urban-Rural-Population.htm|work=Population Division, United Nations|accessdate=4 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709002731/http://esa.un.org/unup/CD-ROM/Urban-Rural-Population.htm|archivedate=9 July 2013|df=}} ==Cities== The World has hundreds of major cities spread across 6 continents. Most are in coastal regions. {{As of|2005}}, the World had 62 metropolitan areas with a population of over 3,000,000 people each.[http://www.mongabay.com/igapo/2005_world_city_populations/2005_city_population_01.html 2005 World City Populations] As of 2010, about 3 billion people live in or around urban areas. Retrieved 3 July 2008.||15,158 |- |9||[[Dhaka]] ||align=right|14,648,000||{{BGD}}||Metropolitan area (megacity)||1,600||9,155 |- |10||[[Istanbul]]||align=right|14,160,467||{{TUR}}||Metropolitan Municipality||5,461||2,593 |} == Population density == {{See also|List of countries by population density}} [[File:Population density countries 2018 world map, people per sq km.svg|300px|thumb|Population density (people per km2) by country, 2018]] The [[world's population]] is 7 billion[https://www.census.gov/main/www/popclock.html U.S. & World Population Clocks] and [[Earth]]'s total area (including land and water) is 510 million square kilometers (197 million square miles).[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html CIA - The World Factbook] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5nDzbMmsd?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |date=1 February 2010 }} Therefore, the worldwide human population density is 7 billion ÷ 510 million = 13.7 per km² (35.5 per sq. mile). If only the Earth's land area of 150 million km² (58 million sq. miles) is taken into account, then human population density increases to 46.7 per km² (117.2 per sq. mile). This calculation includes all continental and island land area, including [[Antarctica]]. If Antarctica is also excluded, then population density rises to 50 people per km² (129.28 per sq. mile).[http://geography.about.com/od/populationgeography/a/popdensity.htm About.com] Considering that over half of the Earth's land mass consists of areas inhospitable to human inhabitation, such as deserts and high mountains, and that population tends to cluster around seaports and fresh water sources, this number by itself does not give any meaningful measurement of human population density. Several of the most densely populated territories in the world are [[city-states]], [[microstates]] or [[Dependent territory|dependencies]].{{cite journal | url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/wpp2008/wpp2008_text_tables.pdf | title=World Population Prospects, Table A.1| version=2008 revision | format=PDF | publisher=United Nations | author=Department of Economic and Social Affairs Population Division | year=2009 | accessdate= 12 March 2009}}The Monaco government uses a smaller surface area figure resulting in a population density of 18,078 per km2 These territories share a relatively small area and a high [[urbanization]] level, with an economically specialized [[city]] population drawing also on rural resources outside the area, illustrating the difference between high population density and [[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]]. == Population distribution == {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = Population distribution | other = | label1 = Asia | value1 = 60.3 | color1 = khaki | label2 = Africa | value2 = 14.5 | color2 = saddlebrown | label3 = Europe | value3 = 11.4 | color3 = cornsilk | label4 = North America | value4 = 7.6 | color4 = wheat | label5 = South America | value5 = 5.6 | color5 = peru | label6 = Oceania | value6 = 0.5 | color6 = burlywood | label7 = Antarctica | value7 = 0.00002 | color7 = white }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Some [[Western civilization|countries with a historically large Christian population]] have experienced a significant decline in the numbers of professed active Christians: see [[demographics of atheism]]. Symptoms of the decline in active participation in Christian religious life include declining recruitment for the [[priest]]hood and [[monastery|monastic life]], as well as diminishing attendance at [[Church service|church]]. On the other hand, since the 19th century, large areas of [[sub-Saharan Africa]] have been converted to Christianity, and this area of the world has the highest population growth rate. In the realm of [[Western civilization]], there has been an increase in the number of people who identify themselves as [[secular humanism|secular humanists]]. In many countries, such as the People's Republic of China, communist governments have discouraged religion, making it difficult to count the actual number of believers. A youth bulge is evident for [[Demographics of Africa|Africa]], and to a lesser extent for West Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia and parts of the Americas.]] {{Main article|Population pyramid|List of countries by median age}} According to the 2006 [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]], around 27% of the world's population is below 15 years of age.[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html#People Age structure of the world] – 2006 [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]] * 0–14 years: 26.3% (male 944,987,919/female 884,268,378) * 15–64 years: 65.9% (male 2,234,860,865/female 2,187,838,153) * 65 years and over: 7.9% (male 227,164,176/female 289,048,221) (2011 est.) * Median Age - 28.4 years (male: 27.7 years, female: 29 years, 2009 est.) According to a report by the [[Global Social Change Research Project]], worldwide, the percent of the population age 0-14 declined from 34% in 1950 to 27% in 2010. On the other hand, the percent elderly (60+) increased during the same period from 8% to 11%.{{cite web|last1=Shackman|first1=Gene|last2=Wang|first2=Xun|last3=Liu|first3=Yalin|title=Brief Review of World Demographic Trends Trends in Age Distributions|url=http://gsociology.icaap.org/report/demsumAging.html|website=The Global Social Change Research Project|accessdate=23 May 2016}} === Population growth rate === [[File:World population growth rate 1950–2050.svg|thumb|300px|Growth rate of world population (1950–2000)
The sharp decline in world population growth in the early 1960s caused primarily by the [[Great Chinese Famine]]]] {{Main article|Population growth}} Globally, the [[Population growth rate|growth rate]] of the [[World population|human population]] has been declining since peaking in 1962 and 1963 at 2.20% per annum. In 2009, the estimated annual growth rate was 1.1%.[https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpop.php U.S. Census Bureau, January 2010] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701122431/http://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpop.php |date=1 July 2009 }} The [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]] gives the world annual birthrate, mortality rate, and growth rate as 1.915%, 0.812%, and 1.092% respectively[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html World Factbook ] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5nDzbMmsd?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |date=1 February 2010 }} The last one hundred years have seen a rapid increase in population due to [[History of medicine#Modern medicine|medical advances]] and massive increase in agricultural productivity{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/4994590.stm |title=The end of India's green revolution? |work=BBC News |date=29 May 2006 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} made possible by the [[Green Revolution]].[http://www.foodfirst.org/media/opeds/2000/4-greenrev.html Food First/Institute for Food and Development Policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090714215036/http://www.foodfirst.org/media/opeds/2000/4-greenrev.html |date=14 July 2009 }}http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0724/p01s01-wogi.html{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.com/irelandbusinessnews/publish/article_1011078.shtml |title=Irish business news |work=Finfacts |date= |accessdate=6 September 2018}} [[File:1 world map 2010-2015 population increase rate by country.svg|thumb|left|upright=1.25|2010-2015 net population increase rate, per 1000 people]] The actual annual growth in the number of humans fell from its peak of 88.0 million in 1989, to a low of 73.9 million in 2003, after which it rose again to 75.2 million in 2006. Since then, annual growth has declined. In 2009, the human population increased by 74.6 million, which is projected to fall steadily to about 41 million per annum in 2050, at which time the population will have increased to about 9.2 billion. Each region of the globe has seen great reductions in growth rate in recent decades, though growth rates remain above 2% in some countries of the [[Middle East]] and [[Sub-Saharan Africa]], and also in [[South Asia]], [[Southeast Asia]], and [[Latin America]].[https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpop.php U.S. Census Bureau, June 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701122431/http://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpop.php |date=1 July 2009 }} Some countries experienced [[Population decline|negative population growth]], especially in [[Eastern Europe]] mainly due to low [[fertility rate]]s, high death rates and [[emigration]]. In [[Southern Africa]], growth is slowing due to the high number of [[HIV]]-related deaths. Some [[Western Europe]] countries might also encounter negative population growth.[http://esa.un.org/unpp/index.asp?panel=2 UN population projections] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5tpNJ6FqS?url=http://esa.un.org/unpp/index.asp?panel=2 |date=28 October 2010 }} [[Japan]]'s population began decreasing in 2005.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/02/japan-population |title=Japan sees biggest population fall |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=6 September 2018}} Population in the world increased from 1990 to 2008 with 1,423 million and 27% growth. Measured by persons, the increase was highest in [[India]] (290 million) and [[China]] (192 million). According to the [[The World Factbook|CIA - The World Factbook]], the country with the highest birth rate currently is Niger at 51.26 births per 1000 people. The country with the lowest birth rate is Japan at 7.64 births per 1000 people. Hong Kong, a Special Administrative Region of China, is at 7.42 births per 1000 people. As compared to the 1950s, birth rate was at 36 births per 1000 in the 1950s,[http://www.uneca.org/eca_programmes/food_security_and_sustainability/programme_overview/population/fertility/crude_world.htm Uneca.org: Crude Birth Rates - The World and its Major Regions, 1950-2050] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816073652/http://www.uneca.org/eca_programmes/food_security_and_sustainability/programme_overview/population/fertility/crude_world.htm |date=16 August 2011 }} birth rate has declined by 16 births per 1000 people. In July 2011, the U.S. National Institutes of Health announced that the adolescent birth rate continues to decline.[http://www.nih.gov/news/health/jul2011/nichd-07.htm Federal report shows drop in adolescent birth rate, July 7, 2011 News Release - National Institutes of Health (NIH)] Birth rates vary even within the same geographic areas. In Europe, as of July 2011, Ireland's birth rate is 16.5 per cent, which is 3.5 per cent higher than the next-ranked country, the UK. France has a birth rate of 12.8 per cent while Sweden is at 12.3 per cent.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/ireland-has-one-of-highest-birth-and-lowest-death-rates-in-eu-189080-Jul2011/ |title=Ireland has one of highest birth and lowest death rates in EU |work=Thejournal.ie |date=29 July 2011 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} In July 2011, the UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS) announced a 2.4% increase in live births in the UK in 2010 alone.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/jul/13/more-midwives-birth-rate-40-year-high |title=Call for more midwives as birth rate reaches 40-year high |work=The Guardian |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} This is the highest birth rate in the UK in 40 years. By contrast, the birth rate in Germany is only 8.3 per 1,000, which is so low that both the UK and France, which have significantly smaller populations, produced more births in 2010.{{cite news |author=|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/health/2011/0809/1224302081071.html |title=Germany faces up to its kinder surprise |work=The Irish Times |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} Birth rates also vary within the same geographic area, based on different demographic groups. For example, in April 2011, the U.S. CDC announced that the birth rate for women over the age of 40 in the U.S. rose between 2007 and 2009, while it fell among every other age group during the same time span.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/04/01/cdc.births.decline/index.html |title=CDC records rise in birth rate for women over 40 |work=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=6 September 2018}} In August 2011, Taiwan's government announced that its birth rate declined in the previous year, despite the fact that it implemented a host of approaches to encourage its citizens to have babies.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14525525 |title=Taiwanese birth rate plummets despite measures |work=BBC News |date= |accessdate=6 September 2018}} Birth rates ranging from 10-20 births per 1000 are considered low, while rates from 40-50 births per 1000 are considered high. There are problems associated with both an extremely high birth rate and an extremely low birth rate. High birth rates can cause stress on the government welfare and family programs to support a youthful population. Additional problems faced by a country with a high birth rate include educating a growing number of children, creating jobs for these children when they enter the workforce, and dealing with the environmental effects that a large population can produce. Low birth rates can put stress on the government to provide adequate senior welfare systems and also the stress on families to support the elders themselves. There will be less children or working age population to support the constantly growing aging population. === Death rate ===

Of the roughly 150,000 people who died each day across the globe, about two thirds—100,000 per day—died of age-related causes in 2001, according to an article which counts all deaths "due to causes that kill hardly anyone under the age of 40" as age-related.{{cite journal | last = Aubrey D.N.J | first = de Grey | authorlink = Aubrey de Grey | title = Life Span Extension Research and Public Debate: Societal Considerations | journal = Studies in Ethics, Law, and Technology | volume = 1 | issue = 1, Article 5 | year = 2007 | url = http://www.sens.org/files/pdf/ENHANCE-PP.pdf | format = PDF | doi = 10.2202/1941-6008.1011 | accessdate = 7 August 2011}}{{bettersource|| reference uses an extremely broad definition of "age-related" deaths, including even traffic accidents due to poor eyesight|date=June 2018}} In industrialized nations, the proportion was even higher according to that article, reaching 90%. === Sex ratio === [[File:Sex ratio total population.PNG|thumb|right|300px|Map indicating the human sex ratio by country. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width:100%; background:none;" |- |valign="top"| {{Legend|#E66771|Countries with more '''females''' than males.}} {{Legend|#7CFC00|Countries with '''similar''' number of males and females.}} {{Legend|#318CE7|Countries with more '''males''' than females.}} {{Legend|Grey|No data}} |}]] The [[Northern Mariana Islands]] have the highest female ratio with 0.77 males per female. [[Qatar]] has the highest male ratio, with 2.87 males/female. For the group aged below 15, [[Sierra Leone]] has the highest female ratio with 0.96 males/female, and the [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]] and the [[China|People's Republic of China]] are tied for the highest male ratio with 1.13 males/female (according to the 2006 [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]]). The value for the entire [[world population]] is 1.02 males/female,{{cite web|title=CIA Fact Book |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |publisher=The Central Intelligence Agency of the United States |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nDzbMmsd?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |archivedate=1 February 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} with 1.07 at birth, 1.06 for those under 15, 1.02 for those between 15 and 64, and 0.78 for those over 65. The "[[First World]]" [[G7]] members all have a sex ratio in the range of 0.95–0.98 for the total population, of 1.05–1.07 at birth, of 1.05–1.06 for the group below 15, of 1.00–1.04 for the group aged 15–64, and of 0.70–0.75 for those over 65. Countries on the [[Arabian Peninsula]] tend to have a 'natural' ratio of about 1.05 at birth but a very high ratio of males for those over 65 ([[Saudi Arabia]] 1.13, [[United Arab Emirates]] 2.73, [[Qatar]] 2.84), indicating either an above-average mortality rate for females or a below-average mortality for males, or, more likely in this case, a large population of aging male [[foreign worker|guest workers]]. Conversely, countries of [[Eastern Europe]] (the [[Baltic states]], [[Belarus]], [[Ukraine]], [[Russia]]) tend to have a 'normal' ratio at birth but a very low ratio of males among those over 65 (Russia 0.46, Latvia 0.48, Ukraine 0.52); similarly, [[Armenia]] has a far above average male ratio at birth (1.17), and a below-average male ratio above 65 (0.67). This effect may be caused by [[human migration|emigration]] and higher male mortality as result of higher post-Soviet era deaths; it may also be related to the enormous (by western standards) rate of alcoholism in the former Soviet states. Another possible contributory factor is an aging population, with a higher than normal proportion of relatively elderly people: we recall that due to higher differential mortality rates the ratio of males to females reduces for each year of age. === Total fertility rate === {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; text-align:left" |+ World historical and predicted total fertility rates (1950–2100)
UN, medium variant, 2012 rev.[http://esa.un.org/wpp/Excel-Data/fertility.htm Esa.un.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417054547/http://esa.un.org/wpp/Excel-Data/fertility.htm |date=17 April 2015 }} |- !Years!!TFR!!Years!!TFR!!Years!!TFR |- |1950–1955||align=center|4.95||2000–2005||align=center|2.60||2050–2055||align=center|2.21 |- ||1955–1960||align=center|4.89||2005–2010||align=center|2.53||2055–2060||align=center|2.18 |- ||1960–1965||align=center|4.91||2010–2015||align=center|2.50||2060–2065||align=center|2.15 |- ||1965–1970||align=center|4.85||2015–2020||align=center|2.45||2065–2070||align=center|2.13 |- ||1970–1975||align=center|4.45||2020–2025||align=center|2.41||2070–2075||align=center|2.10 |- ||1975–1980||align=center|3.84||2025–2030||align=center|2.37||2075–2080||align=center|2.07 |- ||1980–1985||align=center|3.59||2030–2035||align=center|2.34||2080–2085||align=center|2.05 |- ||1985–1990||align=center|3.39||2035–2040||align=center|2.31||2085–2090||align=center|2.03 |- ||1990–1995||align=center|3.04||2040–2045||align=center|2.27||2090–2095||align=center|2.01 |- ||1995–2000||align=center|2.73||2045–2050||align=center|2.24||2095–2100||align=center|1.99 |} There is an inverse correlation between [[income and fertility]], wherein [[Developed country|developed countries]] usually have a much lower [[fertility rate]]. Various [[fertility factor (demography)|fertility factors]] may be involved, such as education and urbanization. [[Mortality rate]]s are low, [[birth control]] is understood and easily accessible, and costs are often deemed very high because of education, clothing, feeding, and social amenities. With wealth, contraception becomes affordable. However, in countries like Iran where contraception was made artificially affordable before the economy accelerated, birth rate also rapidly declined. Further, longer periods of time spent getting higher education often mean women have children later in life. Female labor participation rate also has substantial negative impact on fertility. However, this effect is neutralized among Nordic or liberalist countries.[http://homepage3.nifty.com/sociology/motion.html Graph Charts of TFR and FLR using Google Motion Chart using World Bank's World Development Index.]{{elucidate|date=November 2012}} In [[undeveloped countries]] on the other hand, families desire children for their labour and as caregivers for their parents in old age. Fertility rates are also higher due to the lack of access to [[contraceptives]], generally lower levels of [[female education]], and lower rates of female employment in industry. ===Unemployment rate=== 8.7% (2010 est.) 8.2% (2009 est.) note: 30% combined unemployment and underemployment in many non-industrialized countries; developed countries typically 4%-12% unemployment (2007 est.) ===Demonym=== The [[demonym]] for Earth's inhabitants is [[wikt:Earthling|Earthling]] or, as either a noun or an adjective, [[wikt:Terran|Terran]]. == Languages == [[File:Simplified Languages of Europe map.svg|300px|thumb|A color-coded map of Europe showing the geographic distribution of languages.]] {{Main article|Language family}} Worldwide, [[English language|English]] is used widely as a [[lingua franca]] and can be seen to be the dominant language at this time. The world's largest language by native speakers is [[Mandarin Chinese]] which is a [[first language]] of around 960 million people, or 12.44% of the population, predominantly in [[Greater China]]. [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is spoken by around 330 to 400 million people, predominantly in the [[Americas]] and [[Spain]]. [[Arabic language|Arabic]] is spoken by around 280 million people. [[Hindi]] is spoken by about 200 million speakers, mostly in [[India]]. [[Bengali language|Bengali]] is spoken by around 230 million people, predominantly in India and Bangladesh. [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] is spoken by about 230 million speakers in [[Portugal]], [[Brazil]], [[East Timor]], and [[Southern Africa]]. There are numerous other languages, grouped into nine major families: # [[Indo-European languages]] 46% ([[Europe]], [[Western Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[North Asia]], [[North America]], [[South America]], and [[Oceania]]) # [[Sino-Tibetan languages]] 21% ([[East Asia]]) # [[Niger–Congo languages]] 6.4% ([[Sub-Saharan Africa]]) # [[Afro-Asiatic languages]] 6.0% ([[North Africa]] to [[Horn of Africa]], and [[Western Asia]]) # [[Austronesian languages]] 5.9% ([[Oceania]], [[Madagascar]], and [[Maritime Southeast Asia]]) # [[Dravidian languages]] 3.7% ([[South Asia]]) # [[Altaic languages]] (controversial combination of Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic families) 2.3% ([[Central Asia]], [[North Asia]] ([[Siberia]]), and [[Anatolia]])Since the Mongolic and Tungusic language families have only a relatively small number of speakers, the majority of the Altaic percentage represents speakers of Turkic languages # [[Austroasiatic languages]] 1.7% ([[Indochina|Mainland Southeast Asia]]) # [[Tai–Kadai languages]] 1.3% ([[Southeast Asia]]) There are also hundreds of [[List of sign languages|non-verbal sign languages]]. ==Education== Total population: 83.7% over the age of 15 can read and write, 88.3% male and 79.2% female {{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} note: over two-thirds of the world's 793 million illiterate adults are found in only eight countries (Bangladesh, China, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Pakistan); of all the illiterate adults in the world, two-thirds are women; extremely low literacy rates are concentrated in three regions, the Arab states, South and West Asia, and Sub-Saharan Africa, where around one-third of the men and half of all women are illiterate (2005-09 est.) {{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} As of 2008, the school life expectancy (primary to tertiary education) for a man or woman is 11 years. {{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} ==See also== {{col div|colwidth=35em}} * [[Demographics of North America]] * [[Demographics of South America]] * [[Demographics of Asia]] * [[Demographics of Africa]] * [[Demographics of Oceania]] * [[Demographics of Europe]] * [[Demographics of Antarctica]] {{colend}} ==References== {{reference style|date=September 2016}} {{Reflist|2}} {{Reflist|group=nb}} {{Demographics by continent}} [[Category:Demographics]] [[Category:World]] [[Category:Earth]] [[Category:Global culture]]

{{Infobox organization |name = European Business Summit |image = EBS logo2017.jpg |image_size = 220 |caption = Emblem |formation = 2000 |organisation = EBS is an initiative of [[BUSINESSEUROPE]] and the [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises|Federation of Enterprises in Belgium]] |location = Brussels, Belgium |motto = Where Business and Politics Shape the Future |website = {{URL|www.ebsummit.eu}} }} '''European Business Summit''' (EBS) is an events and conference organiser, and the creator of one of the largest networking and debating events in Brussels – the annual European Business Summit.
==About EBS==
EBS was founded in 2000 by the FEB ([[Federation of Enterprises in Belgium]]), and later joined in support by BUSINESS EUROPE. From the beginning it's purpose was to bring together policy-makers and [[business leader]]s to discuss contemporary issues affecting the future of Europe, thus helping to [[advocacy|improve the decision-making process]] on the EU-level.
EBS also organises the “Back from Davos” event, whose purpose is to follow up on the conclusions and achievements of the annual meetings of the [[World Economic Forum]] in Davos, Switzerland. The 2018 edition took place on January 30 in Brussels. It took a form of a conversation with [[Jyrki Katainen]] - EU Commissioner Jobs, Growth, Investment and Competitiveness and Daniela Vincenti, Editor-in-Chief at [[EurActiv]].
Moreover, EBS supports events such as Think Digital, EU Energy Summit and the European Defence Industry Summit.
When organising its events EBS works with companies, associations, governments and regional representatives, NGOs, academia and think tanks from across multiple sectors.
==Honorary board==
The Honorary Board of the European Business Summit consists of a number of esteemed figures with significant achievements in the areas of politics and business. Members of the Board include a former Italian Prime Minister [[Mario Monti]], the President of [[BusinessEurope]] Emma Marcegaglia and the CEO of the Solvay Group [[Jean-Pierre Clamadieu]] among others.
==Partnerships and patronage==
EBS, under the provision of the Belgian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is supported by the FEB (Federation of Enterprises in Belgium) and BusinessEurope. EBS also operates under the high patronage of His Majesty the King of the Belgians.
==Annual European Business Summit==
The European Business Summit (EBS) is the EBS’ annual flagship event organised in Brussels. Each year the Summit attracts more than 2,000 participants and 200 high-level speakers from over 60 countries. Previous guests and speakers include heads of state and government, European ministers, EU Commissioners, high-ranking individuals, civil society, and academia. Since 2014 the Summit has been organized in the Egmont Palace in Brussels, Belgium.
The Summit spans 2 days, beginning with an Opening Plenary, followed by numerous sessions dedicated to specific topics correlating with key negotiations taking place at the EU-level in a particular year. The sessions take different forms, from big roundtable discussions for around 200 participants, featuring EU Commissioners and high-level officials as speakers, to Agora discussions for around 100 participants, to more intimate “Meet the Expert sessions” which give the opportunity for the audience to interact with the speakers. The Summit concludes with a Closing Plenary session featuring a distinguished guest speaker. The event is complemented by networking lunches and evening gatherings during which all guests have the chance to exchange views and search for new opportunities for collaboration.
==EBS 2017==
The 2017 edition of EBS took place on May 22–23, 2017 and welcomed a wide range of high-level speakers for key moments including Minister Wolfgang Schäuble who spoke about Europe in a new world, CEO Jean-Pierre Clamadieu on [[Sustainable Development Goals]], former Prime Minister Mario Monti on the future of the [[European economy]], MEP Guy Verhofstadt on the future of Europe, and 10 EU Commissioners speaking on creating a new narrative for Europe.
==EBS 2018==
The 2018 edition of the Summit took place on May 23–24 in the Egmont Palace in Brussels. The theme of this edition was “Leading in a changing world: Europe at the forefront of global [[economic change|economic]], social and political change”. The discussions focused on topics such as [[clean industry]], ethics, trade, security and [[defence industry|defence]], [[digitalisation]], [[energy industry|energy]] and [[Brexit]],
==Media==
Every year the Summit attracts significant media attention, with over 250 journalists from international and European media outlets attending the event. EBS offers media partners exclusive access to high-level speakers, private interview rooms and assistance in scheduling one-on-one meetings.

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Filipinos in Saudi Arabia |image= |population = '''1,020,000–1,500,000, possibly 1,800,000'''<ref name="PBSN"/><ref name="BM"/><ref name="ST"/> |popplace = |langs = [[Filipino language|Filipino]], [[English language|English]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] |rels = [[Islam]], [[Roman Catholicism]] and other [[Christian denomination]]s, |related-c = [[Filipino people]], [[Overseas Filipinos]] }} '''Filipinos in Saudi Arabia''' are either migrants or descendants of the [[Philippines]] living in [[Saudi Arabia]]. Saudi Arabia is currently the largest hirer of [[Overseas Filipinos|Overseas Filipino Workers]] (OFWs),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-164120111.html<!-- Note that this is a subscription site, but the given article preview has the information this ref is supporting-->|title=Saudi Arabia remains No. 1 employer of OFWs|last=Antonio|first=Raymund F.|date=2007-05-29|publisher=Manila Bulletin|accessdate=2009-01-24}}</ref> and has the largest Filipino population in the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000002007 |title=OFWs group in Saudi hails reforms for overseas Pinoy DHs |date=2007-01-30 |publisher=[[Department of Labor and Employment (Philippines)|DOLE]] News |accessdate=2009-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209050804/http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000002007 |archivedate=February 9, 2007 }}</ref> Filipinos make up the fourth-largest group of foreigners in Saudi Arabia,<ref name="PBSN">{{cite news|url=http://philbrgysocietyinnigeria.wordpress.com/2008/06/28/pinoys-in-top-10-foreign-populations-of-16-countries/|title=Pinoys in top 10 foreign populations of 16 countries|last=Garcia|first=Madelaine Joy A.|date=2008-06-28|publisher=PBSN|accessdate=2009-01-24}}</ref> and are the second-largest source of [[remittances]] to the Philippines.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philippinetimes.com.au/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=91&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=830&wpage=1&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1759&hn=philippinetimes&he=.com.au|title=Economist says crisis stretching OFWs’ ability to send money|last=Opiniano|first=Jeremaiah M.|date=2008-08-20|publisher=Philippine Times|accessdate=2009-01-24}}</ref>
==Migration history== Filipinos first arrived in Saudi Arabia in 1973, when a group of Filipino engineers migrated to the country.<ref name="mofa">{{cite web|url=http://www.mofa.gov.sa/Detail.asp?InSectionID=3057&InNewsItemID=37460|title=Ambassador of Saudi Arabia to the Philippines|last=Wali|first=Mohammed Ameen |publisher=Mofa.gov.sa|accessdate=2009-01-24}}</ref> Today, staff at the Saudi Arabian embassy in the Philippines process between 800 and 900 jobs for Filipinos daily.<ref name="BM">{{cite news|url=http://businessmirror.com.ph/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5017:saudi-arabia-will-still-need-rp-medical-professionals-&catid=33:economy&Itemid=60|title=Saudi Arabia will still need RP medical professionals|last=Torres|first=Estrella|date=2009-01-22|publisher=Business Mirror|accessdate=2009-01-24}}</ref> In 2008, Saudi Arabia had 300,000 job orders for Filipinos.<ref name="ST">{{cite news|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2008/apr/06/yehey/ofw/20080406ofw1.html |title=More workers needed for the Middle East |last=Martin |first=Sammy |date=2008-04-06 |publisher=Sunday Times |accessdate=2009-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017134015/http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2008/apr/06/yehey/ofw/20080406ofw1.html |archivedate=October 17, 2008 }}</ref> Later, in the first time hiring Filipino medical professionals, Saudi Arabia announced intentions to hire 6,000 Filipinos as doctors and nurses between 2009 and 2011.<ref name="BM"/> In addition to medical professionals, Filipinos work as automotive workers,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000001123|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023159/http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000001123|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-04|title=POLO mediation improves conditions of 15 Filipino car workers in Saudi Arabia|date=2004-11-11|publisher=[[Department of Labor and Employment (Philippines)|DOLE]] News|accessdate=2009-01-24}} </ref> construction workers,<ref name="job">{{cite news|url=http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000000763|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172012/http://www.dole.gov.ph/news/details.asp?id=N000000763|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-03|title=Deployment of OFWs seen to increase this year -Imson|date=2004-06-22|publisher=[[Department of Labor and Employment (Philippines)|DOLE]] News|accessdate=2009-01-24}} </ref> and engineers,<ref name="mofa"/> as well as in the fields of [[desalination]],<ref name="job"/> petroleum production and processing,<ref name="job"/> telecommunications,<ref name="job"/> and transportation.<ref name="job"/>
==Labor issues== Every year, an unknown number of Filipinos in Saudi Arabia are "victims of sexual abuses, maltreatment, unpaid salaries, and other labor malpractices," because of [[Roman Catholic Church|Religion]] according to John Leonard Monterona, the Middle East coordinator of Migrante, a [[Manila]]-based OFW organization.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://qa.filipinoexpats.com/node/940 |title=OFW rights violation worsens under the Arroyo administration |last=Leonard |first=John |date=2008-07-03 |publisher=Filipino OFWs Qatar |accessdate=2009-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107061353/http://qa.filipinoexpats.com/node/940 |archivedate=2009-01-07 |df= }}</ref> Some Filipinos are attracted and [[Human trafficking in Saudi Arabia|transported to Saudi Arabia illegally]], where they are left stranded without work.<ref name="bulatlat">{{cite news|url=http://bulatlat.com/main/2008/10/25/middle-east-is-%E2%80%98most-distressing-ofw-destination%E2%80%99-migrant-group/|title=Middle East is ‘Most Distressing OFW Destination’ - Migrant Group|last=Olea|first=Ronalyn|date=2008-10-25|publisher=Bulatlat News|accessdate=2009-01-25}}</ref> Between January and August 2008, approximately 800 throughout the country sought help at Migrante chapters,<ref name="bulatlat"/> and 922 others were deported to the Philippines in the first three months of 2008 after overstaying their visa requirements.<ref name="aubrey">{{cite news|url=http://www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/191-ofws-still-stranded-jeddah-says-migrante-saudi |title=191 OFWs Still Stranded in Jeddah, Says Migrante-Saudi |last=Makilan |first=Aubrey S. C. |date=2008-03-01 |publisher=Bulatlat News |accessdate=2009-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501160836/http://www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/191-ofws-still-stranded-jeddah-says-migrante-saudi |archivedate=May 1, 2008 }}</ref> At one point in early 2008, 103 Filipinos stranded in [[Jeddah]] lived in a tent camp under a [[bridge]] before being able to be processed for deportation.<ref name="aubrey"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2008/feb/17/yehey/ofw/20080217ofw3.html|title=24 stranded OFWs in Saudi submit |last=Cueto|first=Francis Earl A.|date=2008-02-17|publisher=The Sunday Times|accessdate=2009-01-25}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=//www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/stranded-ofws-jeddah-had-camp-out-under-bridge-be-repatriated |title=Stranded OFWs in Jeddah had to Camp Out Under Bridge to be Repatriated |author=Aubrey S.C. |date=2008-02-23 |publisher=Bulatlat News |accessdate=2009-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106014327/http://www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/stranded-ofws-jeddah-had-camp-out-under-bridge-be-repatriated |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }}</ref>
==Education== {{seealso|Template:Philippine international schools}} As of February 2006 about 75% of the Philippine international schools represented by the [[Commission on Filipinos Overseas]] (CFO) were located in Saudi Arabia. Community-owned Philippine schools, including the [[International Philippine School in Al Khobar]] (IPSA), the [[International Philippine School in Jeddah]] (IPSJ), and [[International Philippine School in Riyadh]] (IPSR), were by 2006 managed by independent school boards but were initially managed by the diplomatic missions themselves.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp177>Regis, Czarina Valerie A. and Allan B. de Guzman. "[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10671-006-9004-8 A system within a system: the Philippine schools overseas]." ''Educational Research for Policy and Practice''. July 2006, Volume 5, Issue 2, pp 175-183. Published online on September 9, 2006. CITED: p. 177.</ref> As of 2006 Riyadh has 13 Philippine private schools and Jeddah has 5 Philippine private schools.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp180>Regis, Czarina Valerie A. and Allan B. de Guzman. "[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10671-006-9004-8 A system within a system: the Philippine schools overseas]." ''Educational Research for Policy and Practice''. July 2006, Volume 5, Issue 2, pp 175-183. Published online on September 9, 2006. CITED: p. 180.</ref>
Large numbers of Philippine children came to Saudi after many Filipino workers arrived in Saudi Arabia in the 1980s. The first Philippine school in Saudi Arabia, [[Philippine School in Jeddah]] was established after the Philippine Consulate in Jeddah began making efforts to start a school in 1983, and Philippine schools were later established in [[Riyadh]] and other Saudi cities. In 2000 Saudi Arabia had nine accredited Philippine schools.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp177/> By 2005 Jeddah alone had four Philippine international schools, with two more scheduled to open shortly.<ref name=Salud>Salud, Francis R. "[http://www.arabnews.com/node/263863 2 More Filipino Schools to Open in Jeddah]" ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6co2xNDp0?url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/263863 |date=2015-11-05 }}). ''[[Arab News]]''. Thursday 7 March 2005. Retrieved on 5 November 2015.</ref> By 2006 there were 21 Philippine schools recognized by the CFO, reflecting a 133% growth rate from 2000.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp177/>
Community international schools in Saudi Arabia are not required to separate male and female students into separate campuses and are allowed to host social activities with men and women mixed.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp178>Regis, Czarina Valerie A. and Allan B. de Guzman. "[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10671-006-9004-8 A system within a system: the Philippine schools overseas]." ''Educational Research for Policy and Practice''. July 2006, Volume 5, Issue 2, pp 175-183. Published online on September 9, 2006. CITED: p. 178.</ref> Regis and Guzman stated that in private Philippine international schools, unlike in the community schools, many Saudi rules that are not consistent with the [[culture of the Philippines]] are enforced.<ref name=RegisGuzmanp181>Regis, Czarina Valerie A. and Allan B. de Guzman. "[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10671-006-9004-8 A system within a system: the Philippine schools overseas]." ''Educational Research for Policy and Practice''. July 2006, Volume 5, Issue 2, pp 175-183. Published online on September 9, 2006. CITED: p. 181.</ref>
==Recreation and sports== The Filipino (Muslim) community has organized recreation and sometimes tournaments, to meet with fellow friends, relatives and fellow Filipinos.

page.title: German Central Library for the Blind

revision.text:
{{Infobox library | library_name = The German Central Library for the Blind (DZB)
''Deutsche Zentralbücherei für Blinde'' | library_logo = | image =Leipzig Deutsche Zentralbuecherei fuer Blinde.jpg | image_size =200px | caption = | country = [[Germany]] | type = | scope = | established = 1894 | ref_legal_mandate = | location = Gustav-Adolf-Straße 7
04105 [[Leipzig]] | coordinates = | branch_of = | num_branches = | items_collected = | collection_size = 72,300 | annual_circulation = 192,600 | criteria = | legal_deposit = | req_to_access = | pop_served = | members = | budget = | director = Dr. Thomas Kahlisch | num_employees = 77 | website = http://www.dzb.de/ | phone_num = | references = }} The '''German Central Library for the Blind''' ({{lang-de|Deutsche Zentralbücherei für Blinde}}), abbreviated '''DZB''', is a [[public library]] for the [[visually impaired]] located in the city of [[Leipzig]], [[Saxony]], [[Germany]]. Its collection of 72,300 titles is amongst the largest in the [[German speaking countries]]. The institution consists of a lending library, a publishing house, and a research center for [[barrier-free]] communication. It also has production facilities for [[braille book]]s, [[audiobook]]s, and [[braille music]]. The DZB publishes about 250 new titles annually.[http://www.dzb.de/en/about-us.html The DZB: About Us]. Leipzig: DZB, 2011. Retrieved 08-Aug-2012 Founded in 1894, the DZB is the oldest library for the blind in Germany.Dagmar Giersberg: [http://www.goethe.de/wis/bib/dos/bip/sac/en82057.htm Online "All Ears and within Reach – The German Central Library for the Blind in Leipzig."] Bonn: Goethe Institute, November 2006. Retrieved 08-Aug-2012 ==History== A private association, the Society for the Procurement of [[Large-print]] Books and Work Opportunities for the Blind ({{lang-de|Verein zur Beschaffung von Hochdruckschriften und Arbeitsgelegenheit für Blinde zu Leipzig}}), was established in [[Leipzig]] in 1894 to provide blind persons with literature and employment.[http://www.dzb.de/en/about-us/history.html "A Piece of History"], Leipzig: DZB, 2011. {{en icon}} Retrieved 08-Aug-2012 It was set up in a bookseller's house and grew into the first library for blind persons in the [[German Empire]]. Soon afterward the society established its own publishing house and printing press. A [[charitable foundation]], the ''Verein zur Förderung der Deutschen Zentralbücherei für Blinde'', was established in 1916 to support and promote the library. By this time over 5,000 braille volumes were available and it had 1,200 regular users.[http://www.dzb.de/index.php?site_id=8.2#geschichte "Geschichte der DZB"], Leipzig: DZB, 2011. {{icon de}} Retrieved 08-Aug-2012 Following [[World War I]], the number of users rose sharply and by 1926 the DZB had 3,500 users. The [[Great Depression]] forced the library into a rigid austerity, resulting in budget cuts and layoffs. In 1935 the DZB moved into the commercial publishing house ''Druckhaus Klepzig'' on the Täubchenweg in Leipzig. This building was later destroyed in an [[Bombing of Leipzig in World War II|Allied bombing raid]] in December 1943 and over 30,000 of the library's books were lost. What little remained of the collection was set up at an alternative site at [[Döbeln]] in 1944. [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-24637-2089, Leipzig, Zentralbücherei für Blinde.jpg|thumb|235px|right|The DZB in 1954]] In the immediate aftermath of [[World War II]] the DZB moved to new quarters on the Weißenfelser Straße with a collection of 1,802 books. Through a decision of the provincial government on 7 November 1946 the library was declared a public institution. By 1949 the library's collection had reached 10,000 volumes. In 1952 DZB came under the auspices of the [[East German]] Ministry of Education and in 1955 it was subject to the Ministry of Culture. In 1954 the library moved into the building still in use today in Gustav-Adolf-Straße (Gustavus Adolphus Street). Following [[German reunification]] the DZB became an agency of the State Ministry of Science and Arts of the new [[Free State of Saxony]]. ==Collection== As of December 2011 the library holds some 72,300 titles. A research section holds books, periodicals and monographs on visual impairment. In addition, the DZB regularly publishes 18 different journals in Braille and in audio versions. The DZB's collection includes:''DZB in Zahlen und Fakten'', December 2011. [http://www.dzb.de/index.php?site_id=8.2 DZB online] {{icon de}}, retrieved 08-Aug-2012 *72,300 total items **21,900 [[Braille book]]s **19,000 [[DAISY]] [[audiobook]]s **6,100 [[Braille music]] books **5,000 Scientific books and monographs on visual impairment Each year the DZB produces about 250 new titles. It has a staff of 77 employees, 15 of whom are persons with disabilities. According to the DZB, "over 5,000 members use the library's different services." ==Braille music facilities== The "DaCapo" project, funded by the [[Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)|German Federal Ministry of Health]], began at the DZB in 2003 to produce specialty [[sheet music]] for the blind. The goal is not only to make musical scores more widely available to the visually impaired, but also to improve career opportunities for blind musicians. The DZB's research center is also developing processes for the computer-assisted production of sheet music in Braille and as well as transmission services.{{cite encyclopedia|author=Thomas Kahlisch, Matthias Leopold and Christian Waldvogel|title=DaCapo, a Project on Transforming Ink Printed to Braille Notes Semi-automatically|series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science; vol. 3118 |encyclopedia=Computers Helping People with Special Needs|pages=623|date=November 2004|publisher=Springer |location=Berlin / Heidelberg|pmid=|doi=10.1007/978-3-540-27817-7_34|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-3-540-27817-7_34 }} The ''MakeBraille'' rendering service accepts digital [[musical notation]] files over the Internet in [[Capella (notation program)|CapXML]] and [[MusicXML]] formats to produce sheet music in Braille format, available for private, non-commercial uses only. ==See also== * [[DAISY]] * [[List of libraries in Germany]] * [[West German Audio Book Library for the Blind]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Deutsche Zentralbücherei für Blinde zu Leipzig}} * [http://www.dzb.de/en Official Website of the DZB] {{en icon}} * [http://www.blista.de Homepage of the German Institute for the Blind] {{icon de}} {{coord|51|20|41|N|12|21|59|E|display=title}} [[Category:Organisations based in Leipzig]] [[Category:Public libraries]] [[Category:Libraries in Germany]] [[Category:1894 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Libraries established in 1894]] [[Category:Libraries for the disabled]] [[Category:Blindness organisations in Germany]]

{{use British English|date=January 2017}} {{use DMY dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = God's Own Country | image = God's Own Country (2017 film).png | caption = British release poster | director = Francis Lee | producer = {{Plainlist| * Manon Ardisson * Jack Tarling }} | executive producer = {{Plainlist| * Anna Duffield * Diarmid Scrimshaw * Mary Burke * Celine Haddad * Richard Holmes * Paul Webster }} | writer = Francis Lee | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Josh O'Connor]] * [[Alec Secăreanu]] * [[Ian Hart]] * [[Gemma Jones]] }} | music = [[A Winged Victory For The Sullen]] | cinematography = Joshua James Richards | editing = Chris Wyatt | production companies = {{Plainlist| *British Film Institute *Creative England *Met Film Production *Shudder Films *Inflammable Films *Magic Bear Productions }} | distributor = {{ubl|[[Orion Pictures]]
[[Samuel Goldwyn Films]]
{{Small|(United States)}}|[[Picturehouse Entertainment]]
{{Small|(United Kingdom)}}}} | released = {{Film date|df=y|2017|1|23|Sundance|2017|9|1|United Kingdom|2017|10|25|United States}} | runtime = 105 minutes{{cite web|title=God's Own Country|url=https://www.sundance.org/projects/god-s-own-country|website=www.sundance.org|publisher=Sundance Institute|accessdate=11 January 2017}} | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = £1 million | gross = $2.2 million{{cite web|title=God’s Own Country (2017)|url=https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Gods-Own-Country-(UK)#tab=summary|website=the-numbers.com|accessdate=28 January 2018}} }} '''''God's Own Country''''' is a 2017 British drama film written and directed by [[Francis Lee (director)|Francis Lee]] in his feature directorial debut. The film stars [[Josh O'Connor]] and [[Alec Secăreanu]]. The plot follows a young sheep farmer in [[Yorkshire]] whose life is transformed by the arrival of a Romanian migrant worker. The film was the only UK-based production to feature in the world drama category at the 2017 [[Sundance Film Festival]] where it won the world cinema directing award. ==Plot== In Yorkshire, Johnny lives on the family farm with his father, Martin, and grandmother, Deirdre. Due to his father having suffered from a stroke, and his grandmother's age, much of the day-to-day running of the farm falls to Johnny. In his social time, Johnny engages in binge drinking and furtive sexual encounters with other men. Returning late to the farm after such an encounter with a young male auctioneer, he is berated by his father after a calf dies from a [[breech birth]] in his absence. Gheorghe, a Romanian migrant worker, is hired as extra help for [[lambing season]]. He arrives and spends his first night in a caravan that the family has organized as his accommodation. As the ewes have moved away from the main part of the farm, and as part of the farm's boundary wall remains unrepaired by Johnny, it is decided that Johnny and Gheorghe should spend several days camping nearer to the animals. When one of the ewes gives birth to an unconscious runt, Johnny is intrigued when Gheorghe is able to resuscitate and care for it. One morning, after Johnny refers to Gheorghe yet again as a "[[gypsy]]," Gheorghe tackles him to the ground and warns Johnny not to speak that way to him again. The next day, the two men again engage in a fight that turns into rough sex. While Johnny initially does not acknowledge the encounter, the two share cigarettes and a sugar packet{{cite web | url =http://anthemmagazine.com/screen-test-alec-secareanu/ | title =Screen Test: Alec Secareanu | last =Chang | first =Kee | date =26 October 2017 | website =Anthem Magazine | publisher = | access-date =4 March 2018 | quote = "We see that echoed around the campfire when he sneaks packets of sugar into his instant rice cups, right? I thought it was drugs at first." "Yes, it’s sugar packets. That’s what keeps him going."}} for their [[cup noodles]] throughout the day. That night, Gheorghe resists Johnny's aggressive move to have sex, instead patiently showing him that sex can also be tender, and the two men kiss for the first time. Returning to the farm, Johnny invites Gheorghe to stay with him in the house, but Gheorghe elects to remain in the caravan. When Martin suffers a second stroke, Johnny realizes that the running of the farm is now entirely his responsibility, and asks Gheorghe if he will stay with him. When Gheorghe expresses uncertainty over whether they can stay together and maintain the farm simultaneously, Johnny reacts poorly, over-drinking and engaging in another random sexual encounter. When Gheorghe realises what Johnny has done, he abruptly leaves the farm. Martin is released from the hospital, but is now fully debilitated. Johnny, desperate to make up with Gheorghe, tells his father that he will stay to run the farm, but that things must be run on his terms. Martin gives his tacit approval to Johnny, who sets off to bring Gheorghe back to the farm. After he finds Gheorghe working in Scotland, the two men reconcile. Gheorghe returns with Johnny; the caravan is taken away, and Gheorghe moves into the house.{{cite news|last1=Rahman|first1=Miran|title=Planned feature film could receive key funding support|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/11399303.Planned_feature_film_could_receive_key_funding_support/|accessdate=11 January 2017|work=Bradford Telegraph and Argus|date=9 August 2014}}{{cite web|title=British Council Film: God's Own Country|url=http://film.britishcouncil.org/gods-own-country|website=film.britishcouncil.org|publisher=British Film Council|accessdate=11 January 2017}} ==Cast== * [[Josh O'Connor]] as Johnny Saxby * [[Alec Secăreanu]] as Gheorghe Ionescu * [[Ian Hart]] as Martin Saxby * [[Gemma Jones]] as Deidre Saxby{{cite web|title=God's Own Country full cast and crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5635086/fullcredits|website=imdb.com|accessdate=11 January 2017|date=23 January 2017}} ==Production== The film is partly based on writer and director Francis Lee's own life, where he also had to make a decision to either stay and work on his family's farm or go off to drama school.{{cite web|last1=Rosser|first1=Michael|title='God's Own Country' cast revealed as shoot begins|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/gods-own-country-cast-revealed-as-shoot-begins/5101798.article#|website=screendaily.com|accessdate=11 January 2017}} The film was shot in [[Yorkshire]], specifically around the [[Silsden]] area of [[Keighley]] in [[West Yorkshire]], with some other scenes being shot in [[Keighley Bus Station]]{{cite news|last1=Knights|first1=David|title=New movie God's Own Country filmed at Keighley bus station|url=http://www.keighleynews.co.uk/news/14462790.New_movie_God_s_Own_Country_filmed_at_Keighley_bus_station/|accessdate=11 January 2017|work=Keighley News|date=29 April 2016}} and [[Airedale General Hospital]] with [[Haworth]] and [[Otley]] also featuring as backdrops for the film. The production was part financed through the British Film Council's iFeature programme with additional funding being secured from Creative England. ==Release== The film had its world premiere at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] on 23 January 2017. It was the only production from the United Kingdom that featured in the world drama category in the 2017 [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|title=Shudder Films’ First Completed Feature Selected for Premiere at Sundance ‹ News and Opportunities ‹ Homepage|url=http://northernmedia.org/news/shudder-films-first-completed-feature-selected-for-premiere-at-sundance|website=NFM|accessdate=11 January 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Sherwin|first1=Adam|title=Sundance Film Festival to premiere Yorkshire sheep farming movie|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/culture/film/sundance-film-festival-chooses-yorkshire-sheep-farming-movie-world-premiere/|accessdate=11 January 2017|work=iNews|date=1 December 2016}} It went onto screen at the [[Berlin International Film Festival]] on 11 February 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/programm/berlinale_programm/datenblatt.php?film_id=201711895#tab=video25|title=God's Own Country|website=[[Berlin International Film Festival]]|accessdate=15 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/berlin-rounds-out-panorama-lineup-call-me-by-your-name-luca-guadagnino-armie-hammer-sundance-gods-own-country-1201893790/|title=Berlin Rounds Out Panorama Lineup, Adds ‘Call Me By Your Name’ & ‘God’s Own Country’|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Diana|last=Lodderhose|date=6 February 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}} Shortly after, [[Picturehouse Entertainment]], [[Orion Pictures]] and [[Samuel Goldwyn Films]] acquired U.K. and U.S. distribution rights respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/picturehouse-takes-sundance-hit-gods-own-country-for-uk/5114607.article|title=Picturehouse takes Sundance hit 'God's Own Country' for UK|website=[[Screen International]]|first=Tom|last=Grater|date=6 February 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/orion-pictures-samuel-goldwyn-films-acquire-gods-own-country-1202086652/|title=Orion Pictures, Samuel Goldwyn Films Land ‘God’s Own Country’ For U.S.|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Nancy|last=Tartaglione|date=8 May 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}} It was released in the United Kingdom on 1 September 2017.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/festivals/gods-own-country-to-open-edinburgh-film-festival-1202419463/|title=‘God’s Own Country,’ Gay Love Story That Premiered at Sundance, to Open Edinburgh Film Festival|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Robert|last=Mitchell|date=9 May 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}} The film was banned in some [[Arab countries]] due to explicit sex scenes between the two protagonists.{{cite web |url=https://www.click.ro/vedete/romanesti/film-cu-romani-interzis-unele-tari-din-cauza-scenelor-prea-deocheate |title=Film cu români, interzis în unele țări din cauza scenelor prea deocheate |work=Click! |author=Gheorghe Chelu |date=16 November 2017 |language=Romanian}} Likewise, [[Romania]] was the only country in [[Eastern Europe]] where the film was screened. ==Reception== [[File:Josh O'Connor at the 6th Odessa International Film Festival (4).jpg|thumb|O'Connor's performance was praised by critics|upright]] ''God's Own Country'' received critical acclaim. It holds a 99% approval rating on review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 102 reviews, with a [[Weighted arithmetic mean|weighted average]] of 8.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads: "A quiet, moving rumination on loneliness and newfound intimacy, ''God's Own Country'' marks an outstanding directorial debut for Francis Lee." {{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/gods_own_country_2017/|title=God's Own Country|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=3 February 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film holds a rating of 85 out of 100, based on 22 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/gods-own-country|title=God's Own Country|website=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=3 February 2018}} The Sundance Film Festival's listing for ''God's Own Country'' says that "you can smell the mud in this movie" while also describing Francis Lee as a major new talent and the film as "one not to be missed." [[Peter Bradshaw]], writing in ''The Guardian'', gave the film four stars out of five. Bradshaw described the film as "an almost, but not quite a Dales ''[[Brokeback Mountain|Brokeback]],''" and also as a "very British love story, bursting at the seams with unspoken emotions, unvoiced fears about the future, and a readiness to displace every emotion into hard physical work".{{cite news|last1=Bradshaw|first1=Peter|title=God's Own Country review – Dales answer to Brokeback that's a very British love story|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/jan/22/gods-own-country-review-a-dales-answer-to-brokeback-thats-a-very-british-love-story|accessdate=29 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=22 January 2017}} At the [[2017 Berlin International Film Festival]] the film received the Harvey Award, presented by the [[Teddy Awards]] programme for LGBT-related films in conjunction with a reader jury from the German LGBT magazine ''[[Männer (magazine)|Männer]]''. Ed Potton, writing in ''The Times'', gave the film four stars out of five and described the film as "splendid" and "[a] potent film, a Yorkshire ''Brokeback Mountain''".{{cite news|last1=Potton|first1=Ed|title=It's Brokeback on the moors|work=The Times|issue=72317|date=1 September 2017|location=Times 2|page=8|issn=0140-0460}} ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width: 99%;" |- ! {{Refimprove|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox prepared food | name = High Energy Biscuits | image = File:US Navy 071203-N-1831S-159 Boxes of relief supplies are piled near Bangladeshi citizens affected by Tropical Cyclone Sidr.jpg | caption = High Energy Biscuits delivered to Bangladesh after [[Cyclone Sidr]] | alternate_name = | country = | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Biscuit]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Cereal]]s and [[vegetable fat]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''High Energy Biscuits''' (HEB) are [[wheat]] [[biscuit]]s containing high-[[protein]] [[cereal]]s and [[vegetable fat]]. Because of their high energy-to-weight ratio they are procured by the [[World Food Programme]], the [[food aid]] branch of the [[United Nations]], for feeding disaster victims worldwide.<ref name="Em5">{{cite web |url=http://www.em5aid.com/heb.php |title=Em5 Aid-High Energy Biscuits |publisher=Em5aid.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215065840/http://em5aid.com/heb.php |archive-date=2015-02-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
HEBs have been provided to a variety of geographical locations. For example, HEBs were delivered to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] after the [[2008 South Ossetia war]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wfp.org/english/?ModuleID=137&Key=2907 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823203656/http://www.wfp.org/english/?ModuleID=137&Key=2907 |archivedate=2008-08-23 |df= }} </ref> HEBs were also airlifted to [[Kenya]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wfp.org/english/?ModuleID=137&Key=2294 |accessdate=August 22, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813184431/http://www.wfp.org/english/?ModuleID=137&Key=2294 |archivedate=August 13, 2008|title=High energy biscuits airlifted to Kenya to feed 200,000 flood victims }}</ref> and more recently distributed in aid in the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]],<ref>[http://www.star-telegram.com/190/story/1894280.html] {{dead link|date=September 2013}}</ref> and 80 tonnes of high energy biscuits were delivered to the Tunisian border in response to the Libyan crisis.<ref>[http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=567469] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301103759/http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=567469 |date=March 1, 2011 }}</ref>
HEBs are usually packaged in cardboard boxes weighing 10 kg each.<ref name="comp">{{cite web|url=https://wfpen.ernsystems.com/publicfiles/HighEnergyBiscuits.pdf |accessdate=August 22, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327005543/https://wfpen.ernsystems.com/publicfiles/HighEnergyBiscuits.pdf |archivedate=March 27, 2009 |title=High Energy Biscuits }}</ref>
==Composition== Per 100 g, HEBs have a minimum of 450 kcal of energy, 4.5% maximum moisture, a minimum of 10-15 g of protein, a minimum of 15 g fat, and 10-15 g sugar at a maximum.<ref name="comp"/>
HEBs have the following micronutrients at a minimum per 100 g:<ref name="comp"/> {| class="wikitable" |- | Calcium || 250 mg |- | Magnesium || 150 mg |- | Iron || 11 mg |- | Iodine || 75 µg |- | Folic acid || 80 µg |- | Pantothenic acid || 3 mg |- | Vitamin B<sub>1</sub> || 0.5 mg |- | Vitamin B<sub>2</sub> || 0.7 mg |- | Vitamin B<sub>6</sub> || 1.0 mg |- | Vitamin B<sub>12</sub> || 0.5 µg |- | Niacin || 6 mg |- | Vitamin C || 20 mg |- | Vitamin A-retinol || 250 µg |- | Vitamin D || 1.9 µg |- | Vitamin E || 5.0 mg |}

''Ungarn in Deutschland {{·}} Németországi magyarok'' |image =Staatsangehörigkeit Ungarn in Deutschland.png |caption=Distribution of Hungarian citizens in Germany (2014) |population='''120,000 Hungarian in Germany''' |popplace= [[Germany]]: Mainly [[Bavaria]], [[Baden-Württemberg]] and [[Hesse]] |langs= Predominantly [[German language|German]] followed by [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] |rels= Predominantly [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] and [[Calvinism|Calvinist]]
Minority [[Atheism|Atheist]] |related= Other [[Hungarian people]] }} There are around 120,000 '''Hungarians in Germany'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.buod.de/H/kere-h.htm|title=General Information - Hungarians in Germany|work=Association of Hungarian Organisations in Germany|language=Hungarian|accessdate=2009-10-25 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207091501/http://buod.de/H/kere-h.htm |archivedate=2009-02-07 }} Hungarians have emigrated here since the Middle Ages. However, after World War I, their number continues to grow at an increased pace. Today, around 75% of this population live in the states of [[Bavaria]], [[Baden-Württemberg]] and [[Hessen]]. ==Population== Only about 60% arrived with a Hungarian passport, as many of them arrived from areas of the former [[Kingdom of Hungary]] (see [[Treaty of Trianon]], 1920). Major population changes: *About 30,000 arrived [[Hungary during World War II|after 1945]] *About 25,000 arrived after the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]] *25,000 [[Gastarbeiter]] from [[Yugoslavia]] after 1960 *Around 5,000 migrants from Czechoslovakia after the [[Prague Spring]] of 1968 *Approx. 30,000 [[Hungarians in Romania|Hungarians from Transylvania]] after 1975 *About 15,000 fleeing [[People's Republic of Hungary|communism in Hungary]] *15,000 moving to [[East Germany]] (until the 1990 [[German reunification]]) ==Culture== In 2006/2007, Hungary presented its country and culture in Germany with a whole series of cultural events including the exhibition "Germans in Hungary – Hungarians in Germany. European Lives".{{cite web|url=http://www.bundesregierung.de/Content/EN/Artikel/2007/07/2007-07-05-deutsche-und-ungarn-starten-arche-europa__en,layoutVariant=Druckansicht.html |title=Germans and Hungarians launch "Europe's Ark" |work=Press and Information Office of the German Government |accessdate=2016-06-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926231624/http://www.bundesregierung.de/Content/EN/Artikel/2007/07/2007-07-05-deutsche-und-ungarn-starten-arche-europa__en%2ClayoutVariant%3DDruckansicht.html |archivedate=2011-09-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Notable individuals== {{further information|:Category:German people of Hungarian descent}} *[[Albrecht Dürer]], painter (his father moved to Germany from Hungary, his surname refers to their old Hungarian village) *[[Béla Ernyey]], actor *[[Joschka Fischer]], politician, foreign minister, his family was expelled from Hungary in 1946 *[[Imre Kertész]], writer, recipient of the 2002 [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] *[[Kevin Kurányi]], football player (Hungarian on paternal side) *[[Philipp Lenard]], physicist, winner of the [[Nobel Prize for Physics]] in 1905 *[[Franz Liszt]], composer *[[Leslie Mándoki]], musician *[[Dzsenifer Marozsán]], football player, captain of the [[Germany women's national football team]] *[[Willi Orban]] -
